frameDefinitions: The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
Some entity (Theme) starts out in one place (Source) and ends up in some other place (Goal), having covered some space between the two (Path).
This frame contains words for motions or actions an Agent performs using some part of his/her body.
A Self_mover responds to a (real or imagined) danger by moving away from it.
This frame pertains to noise verbs used to characterize motion.
frameExamples: She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
That kite you see just to the right of his head was <t>moving</t> around pretty fast but the camera seemed to catch it ok.
She had <t>fled</t> from DCS facilities several times before..
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location. Note that it is not necessarily a self-mover.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies initially before its change of location.
The <fen>Path</fen> refers to (a part of) the ground over which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels  or to a landmark by which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up in.
<fen>Area</fen> identifies the setting in which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s movement takes place without a specified <fen>Path</fen>.
<fen>Distance</fen> is any expression which characterizes the extent of the Motion.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the Protagonist, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the Motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area in which a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>) occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> uses some part of his/her body to perform the action. <fen>Agent</fen> occurs as the External Argument.
With some verbs in this frame, the <fen>Body_part</fen> involved in the action is specified by the meaning of the verb and cannot be expressed separately.  For example,
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the body movement occurs.
The location within which the movement of a <fen>Body_part</fen> takes place.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living (or self-directed) being which moves under its own power.
<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion involving a landmark which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.

The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location.  In sentences containing a <fen>Cause</fen>, the <fen>Theme</fen> is typically the NP Object.  In other sentences, the <fen>Theme</fen> is normally the External Argument.
The <fen>Source</fen> is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of Motion.
The <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the Motion.
This role identifies the general <fen>Area</fen> in which motion takes place, used particularly if the motion is understood as following a complex or non-linear path.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the motion event takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location of a more specific motion (which has <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, <fen>Goal</fen>, or <fen>Area</fen>).
listRoleExamples: <fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
The explosion made <fex>me</fex> move in a hurry.
The policeman moved <fex>away from the door</fex>.
Jo moved <fex>past Dad</fex> into the hall.
The car moved <fex>into the slow lane</fex>.
Emily moved restlessly <fex>around the room</fex>.
The twig floated atop the water <fex>for about 100 yards</fex>.
A radioactive cloud drifted across Britain <fex>after the fire at the Windscale nuclear factory</fex>.
<fex>The boy</fex> swung his legs.
Pat yawned (*his mouth).
There was singing for joy in the streets, and <fex>everywhere</fex> people lifting their arms into the air.
<fex>Pat</fex> crunched over the fresh snow.
The train rumbled <fex>out of the station</fex>.
The truck roared <fex>through the tunnel</fex>.
The plates clattered <fex>to the floor</fex>.
The fly buzzed <fex>about the room</fex>.
The train screeched into the station <fex>at half past seven</fex>
